text: hi everyone so Anthony sutano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new Young
Fathers album heavy heavy this is a
brand new LP from Scottish experimental
rap Art Pop and Lo-Fi Trio Young Fathers
back with their fourth album to date I
have been covering these guys since
their early tape EPS at the front end of
the 2010s it's been awesome to hear
their progression since even if every
commercial album they've dropped over
the years hasn't blown me away for
example I thought their previous LP
cocoa sugar lacked some of the rawness
and thrills of their initial releases
which I think in a way heavy heavy is
starting to recapture seems like the
trio is hitting a balance this time
around giving fans the textually
creative Sonics that made Young Fathers
so interesting to begin with and
crafting with that songs that have these
really Grand far-reaching builds of
instrumentation that are really really
easy to get lost in espa especially with
many of the Sounds in these mixes
bleeding into each other so aggressively
even though on the surface it sounds so
grimy and chaotic the beauty and Grand
instrumentation still comes across as
really cinematic not to mention this LP
brings a slight and interesting
stylistic change for Young Fathers to
the table as many of the grooves and
vocal lines on this LP have a distinctly
West African feel to them this has been
the case for a lot of the Trio's
previous material but I would say
they're leaning into that sound into
that influence harder than ever now and
doing it in a really wild and eccentric
way take the opening track rice for
example with its fuzzy bass and Dusty
Loops progressively building into these
hype chants these hands can heal these
hands can heal which is orbited by these
pounding snares and ghostly layers of
distant vocal harmonies it's just a
jubilee of sound or maybe the musical
equivalent in terms of its heat and
growth of a wildfire spreading very
rapidly then there's the following I saw
which kicks off with a very hypnotic
rocking guitar riff and the boldest lead
vocals on the entire LP a lot of shouted
proclamations I want your Shield I want
your weapon there's a lot of content
about physical defense but also mental
defense not being susceptible to
manipulation or nonsense which of course
builds into another display of just huge
hard-hitting percussion and layers of
group vocals with mentions of brushing
your teeth and washing your face and the
cleanliness in the context of this track
takes on almost a religious sense then
the tense loops and rhythms on drum
combined with the Psychedelic touches of
production here and there has almost an
Animal Collective quality to it
especially as some of these zany effects
and background vocals going
kind of Enter The Fold but yeah while
the influence for this track is pretty
apparent uh it's it's also kind of great
and brings me back to the visceral Vibes
that came off of anko's earlier material
but Young Fathers takes of course a much
different approach on the vocal end I
also get some anko vibes from the
driving high hats and rubbery base uh on
the track sink or swim later on the
record too the highlights on this record
continue on to the song Geronimo love
the low-key almost ambient first leg of
this track the groove I would say has an
old school trip hop quality to it as
well the build of vocals and
instrumentation is absolutely Heavenly
there's almost a new age feel to it I'm
not the most spiritual guy on the Block
but I will say this track feels like
it's speaking to my soul shoot me down
contrast the song greatly with some very
unique and abrasive vocal samples lots
of threatening shouts from guys who
sound like they are about to open fire
on someone with some massive 808 hits
and some slightly muddy drums this
eventually Smooths out into a series of
vocal passages and instrumentation that
again has this religious experience type
quality to it it's like begging and
hoping to survive under the threat of
violence there is very much a no weapon
formed against me shall prosper type
beat to it the whole thing feels very
literal for pretty obvious reasons but
simultaneously mentions of being shot
down could have a metaphorical quality
about them as well so yeah there are
lots of impressive tracks and moments
throughout this record if there's
anything on this album I feel is lacking
very apparently so it's some of the
endings here because a lot of the tracks
on this thing undergo some really great
gradual Progressive builds but sometimes
that leads the trio into a space where
they don't necessarily know how to end
these tracks or give them a proper
finale there's tell somebody which
brings one of the largest most Reverb
herb soaked and brightest displays of
sound and layers on the entire record it
kind of goes up and up and up and up and
up and doesn't really head anywhere from
there cuts off dissipates evaporates
just kind of dips and while there are
some previous cuts that undergo a
similar progression at least they had
meteor instrumentals and felt like more
of a song than just maybe a build across
their runtime then there's the closing
track which
um I'm still wrapping my head around I
have no earthly ideas to what this is we
get all these huge booming rhythms that
aren't even really that locked into the
tempo they hit hard they're loud but
they feel very sloppy and the vocals uh
Young Fathers layer on top of them are
not really that great either especially
as the singing and shouting gets louder
and more layered there's not really a
gratifying or gradual build to the track
either it sort of feels like they're
just throwing out whatever the heck they
want here and as a result the whole song
ends in this utterly horrid cacophony in
my opinion this leads to the most
glaring misstep on the entire record
which really kind of speaks to this
Project's overall issue with not really
knowing how to end things because uh
yeah the closing track here is just a
gigantic face plant in my view still
with that being said even though the
finishing cut on this thing is a massive
disappointment uh the rest of the record
is fire really good honestly I think
better than young father's last and one
of their better projects overall the
songs on this thing are intense those
gradual builds go over really well
across the album The performances are
passionate the production
instrumentation and textures are on
point too and what a cool mix of
influences across the record as well the
record is a little on the short side but
somehow doesn't really feel like it and
I'm really enjoying this project I think
it's a potentially good introduction for
anybody new to the trio as it has been a
while since their last record and it was
most definitely worth the wait feeling a
strong seven to a light eight on this
one transition have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
or the best what should I review next
